description: [Status: stable] [Name: unexpected-special-method-signature] [Message: The special method {} expects {}, {} {} given] What it does Checks for "special" methods that have an unexpected method signature. Why is this bad? "Special" methods, like __len__, are expected to adhere to a specific, standard function signature. Implementing a "special" method using a non-standard function signature can lead to unexpected and surprising behavior for users of a given class. Example class Bookshelf: def __init__(self): self._books = ["Foo", "Bar", "Baz"] def __len__(self, index): # __len__ does not except an index parameter return len(self._books) def __getitem__(self, index): return self._books[index] Use instead: class Bookshelf: def __init__(self): self._books = ["Foo", "Bar", "Baz"] def __len__(self): return len(self._books) def __getitem__(self, index): return self._books[index]
